SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: If I thought so, I should not be very ready to give you more. Come then, tell me the truth; is it so?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page,
SP.P: (pointing to his mother.) Ah! sir, my mama is so poor!

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: (chucking him under the chin.) Good little soul! Have you given up then the only object of your wishes, in order to relieve your mother? It would be very hard, indeed, that you should lose a watch for doing so. (He takes out his own) There! if I had but this single watch, I would give it to you, to reward your affection.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page,
SP.P: (taking it joyfully.) Ah! sir. But does it go!

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Never fear; it goes very well. (The Page runs to his mother, to shew her the watch.)

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Come, my little friend, put up your watch. And since you have made so good use of the little that I gave you, (gives him his purse,) here, take this. There are a hundred guineas instead of the first twelve.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page
SP.P: (looking at him with astonishment.) Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Do you hesitate? Here, take them.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: What, the purse, sir, and all that is — (Going to return it.) Indeed it is too much.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Yes, for yourself. But I give it to you, that you may dispose of it. And who do you think wants it most?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Who wants it? (Looks at the Prince and his mother by turns.) There mama, take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen,
SP.P: (coming forward towards the Prince.) Your highness—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Pray, no acknowledgements, madam. You will find that it is very little, and I fear it may be of more harm to you than advantage. But (pointing to the Page) I need not tell you that this child is too weak and too little for my service. At his age, children are hardly able to do much for others. In short, I hope you will have no objection to take him back again. You are silent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: Your highness will excuse—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: I own, sir, I am wrong to blush for a poverty which I did not bring upon myself, and I may without disgrace ingenuously confess it to my sovereign. (Coming nearer, and looking stedfastly at him.) Yes, fir; my circumstances are too narrow to maintain and bring up my son. I have long looked forward to the future with an anxious eye; and now my fears are real. I shall be the victim of grief. Ah! if I must carry back with me into the sorrowful retreat of misery this child that your highness returns to me, who is the only object of all my concern; this child who is too young as yet— (endeavour∣ing to contain her tears) to—feel the loss of a father— Ah! pardon a mother's weakness.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page,
SP.P: (taking the Prince's hand,) sorrowfully. Mama is crying. sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Well! supposing that you were to live with your mother?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page,
SP.P: (with a look of entreaty.) Your highness won't send me home?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: No? Do you think not? This considence, my little friend, pleases me. Madam, he may stay. And yet it would be a pity if his morals, his innocence—But, no. There is nothing to fear as yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen,
SP.P: (looking at him attentively.) His innocence did your highness say?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: There is no fear, madam. You would imagine perhaps that I wish to draw back my word. But don't be uneasy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen,
SP.P: (fearfully.) Yet, might I take the liberty, without breaking through the respect that I owe your highness, to request you to explain yourself—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Madam, what I meant was this. I have for some time past been extremely dissatisfied with my pages. Their company and example might perhaps—Yet after all it is but a perhaps, and one may try—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen,
SP.P: (eagerly seizing her son's hand.) No, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince,
SP.P: (affecting displeasure.) No? As you please, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: My son's innocence is too dear to me. I shudder at the dangers to which I was going to expose him.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: But consider—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: I consider nothing: I see my son in the midst of the flames; and if I can but save him, no matter, though he should be naked.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: But without fortune, without education, madam, what will become of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: Whatever it shall please heaven. I sub∣mit to the divine will. If he cannot support his birth, let him go labour in the fields; let him die in poverty, but retain his innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince
SP.P: (in his natural manner.) This is thinking nobly. Yes, madam, I see, you deserve every thing that I can possibly do for you. (Coming nearer to her and speaking with earnestness.) In what can I be of assistance to you? Tell me how I can serve you. Only speak, you see a friend before you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen,
SP.P: (with emotion.) Ah! sir—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Tell me first of all what is your situation. How are you with regard to your estate?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: It will be absolutely impossible, sir, for me to save it.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Your debts then are pretty considerable? You are at law now, I am told. Do not they give you any hopes?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: None, sir. One cause, concerning a small inheritance, should have been decided long ago in my favour. My title is indisputable. But interest and money are against it. Necessity brought me hither to town, in order to endeavour a compromise, but I could not succeed.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: So much the better. You shall have justice now, without making any sacrifice, I give you my word of honour; and accept moreover a pension of a hundred a year. I hope that it will put you above every necessity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen,
SP.P: (throwing herself at his feet.) Oh! sir, so much goodness! how shall I—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince,
SP.P: (raising her.) What are you doing, madam? Rise, I request you. I only discharge what I owe to the memory of a man whose widow you are. I do for you no more than I would do for any one whose virtue I esteem∣ed. Tell me, would you still hesitate to take back your child?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: Sir, could I so forget—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: And you, my little friend, would you like to go back with your mother?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page,
SP.P: (playing with his watch.) With my mother? Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: And yet now I know that you love me, would not you like as well to stay with me?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Yes, very well, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Now, if that be so, were I to give you back to your mother, it would be sending you away from me, and you have asked me so earnestly to keep you here. Besides, your mother has thrown you into my arms. I must therefore take another way to settle matters. Stop here, madam, I shall be with you in a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen,
SP.P: (throwing herself into an arm chair.) O blessed day! O unexpected happiness!

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Well, mama; well, are you glad?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen,
SP.P: (drawing him to her affectionately.) O my son, my dear son!

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: But you do not rejoice. You ought to be merrier, mama.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: Even my happiness makes me blush. It reproaches me for the little trust that I had in Providence, and for the sorrow that I felt when you came into the world. It was but a moment after I had heard of the loss of your father. I looked at you with pity, and lamented that you ever saw the light. (She takes him in her arms and kisses him.) Yet it was you that was to relieve your unfor∣tunate mother! your young hands were to dry up her tears! O heaven! what can I now desire more? Nothing, nothing, but to be sure of your brother's lot, and then my happiness would be complete.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: My brother's? Why, mama, what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: If the prince knew what he has done—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: And if he did, there would be nothing of it. You saw how good and how generous he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: To us, my dear, who are not guilty of any crime.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Besides, he promised me that he would not tell, and that the colonel should know nothing of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen,
SP.P: (frightened) What! he promised you!

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Yes, indeed: so you need not be afraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: I am thunder-struck. You have told him then?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Nay, hardly any thing. Only all that I knew. And then he asked me concerning my brother's behaviour, and so I could not tell a fib. You know you bid me never to do so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: But, my dear child—

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Why, mama, are you uneasy?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: Uneasy? O heavens! can you ask? Oh! if the prince should enquire farther, if he should be in∣formed—You may ruin your mother and your brother! you may plunge us all into the deepest misery.

SP.SPEAKER: The Page,
SP.P: (ready to cry.) The deepest misery?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: Somebody comes— (She kisses and encou∣rages him.) Say not a word. Dry up your tears. They will only, perhaps, make the matter worse. Do not be uneasy.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XIII.
DIV3.STAGE: Mrs. Dorffen, the Page, the Prince followed by Captain Derenhoff, and Ensign Dorffen.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Come in, gentlemen. (To the Ensign.) You are ensign Dorffen, then? the son of that brave Major?

SP.SPEAKER: Ensign Dorffen,
SP.P: (bowing very low.) Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: That is a great recommendation with me. Your father was a man of honour and a brave officer. I have no doubt but his example rouses your emulation, and that you strive to make yourself worthy of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Ensign Dorffen.
SP.P: Sir, I only do my duty.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: That is doing every thing. The bravest man can do no more. There, sir, is your mother: her virtues, and the hopes that may be formed of this amiable child, have given me the most favourable idea of your family; and therefore I wished to see you all assembled here.

SP.SPEAKER: Ensign Dorffen,
SP.P: (still bowing.) Your highness does me particular honour!

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: No more, certainly, than you deserve.

SP.SPEAKER: Ensign Dorffen,
SP.P: Your highness judges favourably of me.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Really, sir, I only want to be confirmed in the opinion that I am tempted to form of you at present, in order to make your fortune: and yet that air of free∣dom and confidence that becomes you so well—

SP.SPEAKER: Ensign Dorffen.
SP.P: Ah! sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Denotes (permit me to say) a heart either very noble, or very corrupt. The son of such parents cannot be suspected. Certainly not. Therefore, sir, what can we do to serve you? A step higher would not ad∣vance you much in rank. What think you?

SP.SPEAKER: Ensign Dorffen
SP.P: (rubbing his hands.) No, certainly sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Now, if we were to pass over this step? A Company! the rank of captain! It is the main object with you young gentlemen. But first— (turning short round to Capt. Derenhoff) Sir, what is your opinion of your nephew?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Derenhoff
SP.P: (something confused.) Mine, sir? My opinion?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: One would think it to be unfavour∣able.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Derenhoff.
SP.P: No, sir, rather much the contrary; I believe that he has courage, and will be a brave—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince
SP.P: (looking with satisfaction at ensign Dorffen.) Ay is that true?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Derenhoff.
SP.P: Besides, he has a promising figure.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: He is a fine lad, I confess. But his be∣haviour, his morals? I am ashamed, indeed, to ask you about such trifles. In short, what is his charac∣ter?

SP.SPEAKER: Capt. Derenhoff
SP.P: (smiling.) Oh! a little too airy, some∣times petulant. After all, sir, you know, that does not misbecome a soldier.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: I know? Really that is something new to me. I want now, madam, only your testimony. What will you say of your son?— (After a pause) Nothing?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: What should I say of him?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: What you think. The truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: But can I, sir? If I had reason to praise him, would you wish me to do it in his presence? or should I speak to his prejudice before him who can deter∣mine his fortune?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince,
SP.P: (smiling.) Excellent, madam. To the fondness of a mother you join the address of a woman. I cannot but admire you. (In a serious tone.) Sir, every one has his way. I have mine, when I mean to advance an officer, I begin with putting him under arrest. What do you think of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Ensign Dorffen,
SP.P: (frightened.) Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P:
Yes, that is my manner. Give up your sword to the captain. An air of more modesty would have excused all. But this confidence, this undaunted toe—What can be expected from a person who with your conscience is master of such assurance? who should be sensible that he has deserved my displeasure? who knows how unworthily he has treated the best of mothers? and who nevertheless—Sir, let him be confined for a month. I will have no explanation upon what is past, and that on your account, madam, and because of the manner in which I came by my information; but particularly be∣cause
circumstances make me presume that his fault is of a weighty nature— (With a severe and determined voice.) Captain, if hereafter any thing should happen, I desire to be informed of it immediately, you understand? immedi∣ately. I mean to advance this young man; and neither you (to the captain,) nor (in a gentler tone) you, madam, shall make me alter my plan—Never give him any thing, never the smallest trifle by way of present. His pay may serve him; and let him learn to contract his expences. (Making a sign with his hand.) Go, sir, to your confine∣ment. (The two officers go out.)

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XIV.
DIV3.STAGE: The Prince, Mrs. Dorffen, the Page.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Well, madam, you seem dejected.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen,
SP.P: (respectfully.) Sir, I am a mother.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: But you are not one of those weak mothers, who, to spare their children a slight mortification, chuse not to correct them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: That would be a very false tenderness. No, sir, I only fear that he may have lost for ever his prince's favour.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Do not be uneasy, madam. My design is barely to make him worthy of the favours that I mean to bestow on him. His youth claims some indulgence, therefore I excuse his levities and indiscretion; but I shall not always do so. What in one person brings back the love of virtue along with repentance, will in another strengthen his inclination to vice. Upon the whole, make yourself easy. The young gentleman will come to him∣self, and I shall proportion my favour to his improvement. (Turning to the page.) As to this child, do you know what my intentions are?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: Whatever they are, sir, they will only aim to secure his happiness. O, sir! I have never let pass a day without paying to your virtues the tribute of my homage, but I now see how far it fell below them.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P:
What would you say, madam? You do not know me. My object is to give the state a worthy
member, and myself a faithful servant, and to raise up for my son a friend who may one day be ready to sacrifice his life for him as his father has done for me.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XV.
DIV3.STAGE: The Prince, Mrs. Dorffen, the Page, Attendant.

SP.SPEAKER: Attendant.
SP.P: Please your highness, the Master of the Royal Academy.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Let him come in. I hope, madam, that you need only to be informed of my intentions to approve them.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE XVI.
DIV3.STAGE: The Prince, Mrs. Dorffen, the Page, the Master of the Academy.

SP.SPEAKER: The Master,
SP.P: (bowing.) I am come according to your highness's orders.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Your servant, sir, I am glad to see you. What do children of the first condition pay at the Royal Academy?

SP.SPEAKER: The Master.
SP.P: Of the first condition, sir? That is a pa∣rents agree.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: However, mention the terms.

SP.SPEAKER: The Master.
SP.P: Sixty pounds, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Very well. This child I mean to send to you. And as I shall be instead of a father to him, I propose to do as much for him as the best gentlemen do for their children. But tell me, who has the care of attending to these young persons? for that is the essential point.

SP.SPEAKER: The Master.
SP.P: The different masters, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Who are, I suppose, qualified for their employment. But I do not know them. It is on you alone, sir, that I wish to depend. You have gained my confidence. Would you be so good as to take this child particularly under your own care?

SP.SPEAKER: The Master.
SP.P: Sir, it is my duty.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: I do not mean to make it a duty to you. Will it be agreeable?

SP.SPEAKER: The Master.
SP.P: Sir, my duty is always agreeable to me.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Very well. You may depend then on my gratitude. (To the Page, as he takes him by the hand.) Come hither, my man; do you see this gentleman? he is mild and good-natured; would you like to go and live with him?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page,
SP.P: (after looking a moment at the master.) Yes, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: But observe, you are to look upon this gentleman as your master, as your benefactor. You are to shew him the greatest obedience, and the most dutiful respect; and if ever he has reason to complain of you—

SP.SPEAKER: The Page.
SP.P: Oh! sir, he never shall.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: You have seen that I can be as severe as I am gentle. So that at the smallest complaint—

SP.SPEAKER: The Page,
SP.P: (bowing respectfully to the master.) I hope, sir, you shall never have reason to complain of me.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: How do you like this child?

SP.SPEAKER: The Master.
SP.P: It is enough, sir, that I receive him from your hands; that will make him always dear to me as my own son.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Well then, he may go with you. You have no objection, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: Heavens, sir! objection?

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: Go then, my dear; and never quit the paths of virtue and honour. I have only to add, that you may make yourself easy; you shall never want. But why so dull?

SP.SPEAKER: The Page,
SP.P: (taking the prince's hand.) I wish your high∣ness all happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince,
SP.P: (tenderly.) And I you the same, my good little friend. God bless you, my dear. How grateful his heart is already! Now, sir, you may take him: and you, madam, accompany this gentleman, and see where your son is to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen,
SP.P: (throwing herself at his feet.) Can I leave your highness without humbly—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince.
SP.P: What are you doing, madam? I do not like this.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: Permit me to—

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince,
SP.P: (raising her.) By no means. Rise, madam. I cannot suffer that in any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dorffen.
SP.P: Well, I obey your highness, and take my leave— (Lifting up her hands.) I will bend then before my Maker, and pray him to protect for ever so generous a prince.

SP.SPEAKER: The Prince,
SP.P: (with condescension, accompanying her a few steps.) Farewel, madam, I wish you happy.
